body: @Swollen_members_good I like to think most people reading doujin are in it for the story/quality (otherwise just use pixiv or something) but it still surprises me to see someone dedicated to economic feasibility of their kidnapping fetish. If I make a doujin I'll make sure the office workers papers and budget is balanced before they go down on each other.

This just seems like a poor business model. If it's a whole triad maybe that has this same operation going in multiple locations maybe, but considering that the same people orchestrating the kidnapping also become occupied with the training, that slows down total production. It would be easier to sell them quickly after kidnapping with copious amounts of the drug in them. That way, they can move more product in a shorter amount of time, at maybe a slightly decreased per sale value.

Ahh.. the nHentai comment threads.  Where a guy can go to complain that a fictional story - namely a sexual fantasy that another person has illustrated, does not match his own particular set of fetishes.  And yet the continue to read these stories despite the blacklisted tag feature recently added to the site.  I wonder why?  Is it a macabre fascination?    Or are they upset that their little peepees got hard while reading a culturally subversive trope, thus suggesting their own sexuality is still in its repressed, formative stages?  Sexual subjugation, shota/lolis/futa, guro, NTR,  even handholding can be hot if you have a formidably lewd brain. Personally, I like to see the moralfags and so called "dominant men" here (lol, as if) become outraged.  Struggle against your own sexuality.  It gets me off, truly. :)
